awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Kira Goldner is "Mechanism Design for Social Good".  The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University and the sponsoring scientist is Tim Roughgarden.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI explored the mathematics underlying questions of markets with social impact, including health insurance markets, online labor markets, and emissions trading schemes. The PI produced three publications and one preprint on the topic of the award. 


Intellectual Merit: In the above settings, work by the PI and collaborators showed the following results. (1) They characterized for which populations of health insurance markets it is better for the consumers to have regulated entry of insurance providers into the market compared to a free and open market.  (2) They constructed and analyzed the first mechanism to approximately maximize gains from trade in an online labor market with an employer who wishes to hire different kinds of employees.  (3) They showed the vulnerabilities to strategic behavior of the mechanism used to allocate carbon licenses in Emissions Trading Schemes in practice, and proposed a setting of the mechanism’s parameters in a way that provably guarantees approximate efficiency of the allocation even under strategic manipulation.  (4) They characterized optimal mechanisms for a setting with single-minded agents.


Broader Impacts: The PI worked on three social-impact-focused projects of the domains listed above. She broadly disseminated her work to a variety of audiences: technical theory of computer science audiences, broader computer science colloquium audiences, members of the data science industry, undergraduates interested in research careers, and more. She developed and delivered three tutorials on the topics of her work, which have since been used to develop her graduate course.  The PI also served on the steering committee for the MD4SG 2020 workshop and as part of the founding executive committee for the ACM Conference on Equity and Access in Algorithms, Mechanisms, and Optimization.  The PI mentored two PhD students as part of her projects.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2023
Modified by: Kira Goldner
